thread.title: Local Roundup: Reinhardt game tops NAIA slate
thread.title_full: Local Roundup: Reinhardt game tops NAIA slate

author: Tribune staff reports (noreply@cherokeetribune.com)
title: Local Roundup: Reinhardt game tops NAIA slate
text: Local Roundup: Reinhardt game tops NAIA slate by Tribune staff reports Cherokee Tribune October 21, 2015 01:01 AM | 495 views | 0 | 3 | | Saturday’s Mid-South West showdown between Reinhardt and Lindsey Wilson at Ken White Field was named the NAIA Game of the Week after fan voting through social media. No. 8 Reinhardt (7-0, 2-0) and No. 1 Lindsey Wilson (6-0, 1-0) enter the game as two of only four undefeated teams left in the NAIA. Not only is the game important in terms of national rankings, but it takes on even more importance because it is the first time the teams have been scheduled to play one another as divisional foes.Reinhardt faced Lindsey Wilson in a conference crossover game each of its first two seasons, and both games were close. In 2013, Reinhardt fell behind 44-17 in the its inaugural home game but battled back before losing 50-45. Last season in Columbia, Kentucky, Reinhardt trailed 20-0 before scoring a touchdown with 1:35 left for a 52-48 win.As of Tuesday afternoon, tickets were still available for Saturday’s game at www.reinhardteagles.com/f/tickets.php.♦ ♦ ♦Running back Brittain Brown was named Cherokee’s offensive player of the week, after the Duke commitment ran for 357 yards and three touchdowns in a 28-21 loss to Milton. Christian Vines was awarded on defense after recording five tackles and an interception, and Montrell Washington was named special teams player after totaling 148 yards on kick returns.Marcus Spears was named offensive player of the week for River Ridge after throwing for 109 yards and two touchdowns in the Knights’ 56-14 loss to Dalton. Linebacker Jacob Saylor was recognized for his play on defense and Anthony Hounschell was honored on special teams.Sequoyah’s Trey Mitchell was named his team’s offensive player of the week after rushing for a season-high 111 yards and three touchdowns on 22 carries in a 38-35 loss to Creekview. Linebacker Ethan Bruce made three solo tackles to be named defensive player, while Greyson Van Dyke’s play got him recognized on special teams.Woodstock’s Jerrail McMickens rushed for 107 yards and a touchdown on seven carries to be named the Wolverines’ offensive player of the week. He was joined by linebacker Corey Long on defense and punter Liam Byrne on special teams after Woodstock’s 49-21 loss to Walton.Sam Jones, who rushed for 98 yards and a touchdown on 10 carries in Reinhardt’s 52-18 win over Cumberland, was named the Eagles’ offensive Player of the week. Marcus Miller’s 12 tackles got him recognized on the defensive side of the ball, while Nick Johnson’s interception return on a 2-point conversion attempt led to him being named special teams player. Josh Pierce and Trevor Carlton were awarded as offensive and defensive scout team players of the week, respectively.♦ ♦ ♦Reinhardt’s women’s soccer team had its six-game winning streak snapped with a double-overtime loss to Georgia Gwinnett last Wednesday, but the Lady Eagles bounced back with four straight goals to beat Union 5-1 on Saturday in Barbourville, Kentucky. Allie Hale got the scoring started with a goal from a free kick in the 22nd minute, but Union tied the game just 11 minutes later. After that, it was all Reinhardt.Kristin Clegg knocked in a pass from Megan McCall just seconds later to put the Lady Eagles back in front. Katie Goodrich gave Reinhardt some breathing room with her goal from 20 yards out, and the Lady Eagles pulled away late with Clegg and Hale each recording their second goals in the 68th and 70th minutes, respectively.Colby LaFever was in goal for the first half, and Taylor Asher played the second. Both recorded three saves.The men were not so lucky in their trip, falling 2-1 after forcing No. 11 Union to overtime before losing on a penalty kick.Jordan Williams connected on one of Reinhardt’s four first-half shots to put the Eagles up 1-0 in the 37th minute. They carried that advantage to the half, but the second half was a different story.Reinhardt was unable to muster a single shot on goal in the second half, and a Union goal from just outside the 6-yard box in the 51st minute was enough to send the game into overtime.The Eagles had their chances in the extra period, getting shots from Williams and Matthew Gray, but Reinhardt could not take advantage. That opened the door for Union to score on a penalty kick a short time later to win the game. Although he was unable to save the penalty kick, Reinhardt goal keeper Torge Wiedenroth recorded eight saves.The Reinhardt women (10-2-1, 5-1 Appalachian Athletic Conference) will host Columbia College today in a matchup between the conference’s top two teams. The Reinhardt men (6-6, 4-2) will wait until Sunday when they host Montreat as part of a doubleheader with the women’s team. Share This Article | similar stories
